titleStmt.title: Aratea Digital
Description ofStrasbourg, Bibliothèque nationale et universitaire, Ms 326

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

msDesc.head:
Astronomical-Computistical Collection
Limoges or Angoulême s. X2 (with later additions)

supportDesc.extent:
ii+ 201 fols. + ii (modern paper)
320 255 (exception f. 181 which is of smaller format).
supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in pencil in the upper right corner of every folium.

condition.p: Fol. 1 cut perpendicularly, missing the outer half. Missing leaf (most probably originally left blank) between ff. 172 and 173, now only a small rest visible; two stubs visible also between ff. 169 and 170.
Stanes probably from water damage on ff. 191-201.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 173-179r (Calendar) ruled in 33 long lines; ff. 179v-184v (Tables) in 44-59 lines.
ff. 185r-v written in two columns 44 lines.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Most of the texts are written in a tight carolingian minuscule, which shows characteristics of the tenth century such as: e-caudata, word division, ligatures (ct, st, ra, nt) and abbreviation (-orum, -tur). The script used for the Aratea section exhibits fewer ligatures and seems to be written by a more modern hand (the shaft of the caroline a becoming more up-right, the tongue of the e pointing to 2 o'clock). The same hand wrote probably also ff. 185-201.

decoDesc.decoNote: Rubrics for chapters headings inCapitalis rustica and initial-majuscule for opening the chapter. Later added paragraph marks in red; ample margins left but no glossa.

physDesc.additions: On f.169r a prayer later added in the free space: In nomine patri et filii et spiritus sancti amen. Adiuro uos tempestates et uoces et tonitrua et fulgura . Fol. 181 a later addition.

binding.p: Modern brown shagreen leather binding on six sewing stations.

history.origin: The manuscript is a copy ofParis, BnF, Ms lat. 5239 (s. X1/3, Saint-Martial in Limoges).

listBibl.head: Selected Bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: Buescu, Victor. “Deux Nouveaux Francici de Germanicus César.” InProblèmes de critique et d’histoire textuelle, 229–37. Bucharest and Paris, 1942.

Folkerts, Menso. “De Arithmeticis Propositionibus. A Mathematical Treatise Ascribed to the Venerable Bede.” InEssays on Early Medieval Mathematics, by Menso Folkerts, III. 1–30. Aldershot: Variorum, 2003, here p. 6.

msItem.incipit: Naturas rerum uarias labentis et
msItem.explicit: Quis legit astra super mente tuere deum diem

msItem.note: Capitula.
msItem.incipit: I. De quadrifario dei opere
msItem.explicit: XXV. De aere

msItem.note: Text
msItem.incipit: ratione distinguitur. Primo quod
msItem.explicit: usque ad occidentem extenditur.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De temporibus

msItem.note: Capitula
msItem.incipit: I.De temporibus horis et momentis
msItem.explicit: De sexta aetate.

msItem.rubric: I. De temporibus horis et momentis
msItem.incipit: Tempora momentis horis diebus mensibus annis saeculis aetatibus diuiduntur

msItem.explicit: Reliquum sextae aetatis deo soli patet.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De temprum ratione
msItem.rubric: Praefatio Bedae presbuteri in librum de temporibus
msItem.incipit: De natura rerum et ratione temporum duoscondam per stricto sermone libellos discentibus
msItem.explicit: caelestium premiorum mereamur accipere palmam.
msItem.note: On f.77v the text jumps from chapter 66,10 cuius adiutorio propagaret genuit humanum to chapter 67-71 Haec de cursu praeteriti saeculi .

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.note: Chapter 66.
msItem.incipit: Adam annorum CXXX genuit Sed, cui superuixit annis DCC
msItem.explicit: cum debito tanto patri honore condidit.

msItem.note: Few marginal notes and interlinear, more abundant in the first chapters.

msItem.title: Series annorum mundi nova
msItem.incipit: Adam cum esset CXXX annorum genuit seth. Set autem habens annos CV
msItem.explicit: Sunt autem totius summae ab origine mundi anni usque in presentem annum DCCCX incarnationis dni I̅I̅I̅I̅DCCLXII.

msItem.author: (Ps.) Isidore
msItem.title: De ortu et obitu patrum
msItem.rubric: Incipit de ortu et obitu patrum
msItem.incipit: Adam pater generis humani dei manibus ex terra creatus
msItem.explicit: episcopus missu sibidem requies at in pace.
msItem.note: Taken probably fromLibri computi, I, 6.
Excerpt fromLibri computi, I, 7 C.
msItem.incipit: Ab adam usque ad natiuitatem xri computantur anni I̅I̅I̅DCCCLII Si in primo anno quo adam factus est posueris terminum paschae
msItem.explicit: anno que passionis terminus nonas aprilis et concurens VII.

msItem.note: On different languages and alphabets after the flood. Included are the jewish, greek, and latin alphabets, the one by Aethicus Cosmographus, and the northmen (northmannorum. The name of each letter is transliterated in Latin. At the end is alist of the Roman numerals from one to million MM (in 5 columns), with the corresponding Greek numerals transliterated in Latin letter Mia Ecathostochyle.
msItem.incipit: Primus omnium litteras ante diluuium inuenisse enoch dicitur
msItem.explicit: MM Ecathostochyle.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De arithmeticis propositionibus liber(1.1-3.3)
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt numeri per quos potest qui voluerit aliterius cogitationes de numero quolibet quem animo conceperit explorare
msItem.incipit: Quo modo numerous a quolibet animo conceptus quis sit
msItem.explicit: sexies conteni sextam septies conteni septimam.

msItem.note: Unfinished digram; a large circle.
Computistical tables.
Lunar zodiac table;
Feria table (weekdays coded Sabbato, Dominica and letters II to VI),
Tabula Dionysii;

Five further tables for calculating the weekdays (the first four coded with letters A-G while the fifth with letters Dominica, Lunae, Martis, C andidi circuli , T
, A phroditis , and Saturni. Explanatory text on f. 113v Littere huius laterculi qui uocatur ratio sepri zodiaci eo quod .

msItem.rubric: Argumentum quota sit luna per decem et novem annos
msItem.note: Two Lunar letters AEIOV tables the first with Greek numeralsHaec figura grecis litteris et numeris computatur;
Rota of monthly lunar epacts;
two calendrical rotas (?);
Rota for feria of kalends;

Rota for calculating the zodiacal ascendent, divided in 12 wedge-shaped segments for each of the months accompanied by shortregula (for March: So XI aut XII remanserint oriuntur pisces); Cf. Libri computi, I, 6.

msItem.rubric: Quibus signis orientibus quae occident vel centrum caeli supra vel infra eodem tempore teneant subiecta formula continetur
msItem.note: Rota divided in 12 wedge-shaped segments for calculating the simultaneously rising and setting of the zodiacal signs:ariete oriente II horis occidit libra et centrum superioris zodiaci tunc capricornus inferioris optinet cancer, tauro oriente II horis occidit scorpius et centrum superioris zodiaci tunc aquarius inferioris optinet leo; Cf. Libri computi, I, 6.
Two diagrams of solstices and equinoxes.
Two small rotae of the elements and their qualities and with the season; below ithorologium viatorum with explanatory text Ianuaris cum decembri in horarum mensura concordat .
Text on the winds based onIsidore's De natura rerum, 37.
msItem.incipit: Ventorum primus cardinalis septentrio
msItem.explicit: si circuli similitudinem prudens lector inquirat.

msItem.note: Verse on the winds.
msItem.rubric: Versus de ventorum nominibus ac speris subpositis
msItem.incipit: Quatttuor aquadro consurgunt limite uenti
msItem.explicit: Argestemque grai uocitant cognomina prisco.

msItem.note: Wind diagram rota with twelve wedge-shaped segments with text for each of the twelve winds again based onIsidore's De natura rerum, 37: Ventorum primus cadinalis septentrio qui et a partias frigidus et niualis .

Rota for phases of the moonledo, malina in connection with the tides, in the centre of the rota with T-O centre and four smaller circles on the sides each with text Luna XXVIII incipit malina etc. probably taken from Annalis libellus, c. 51.

Another wind diagram with eight wedge-shaped segments, each divided further in two. Texts inbetween the eight segments each starting with the the letter O:O miranda suo flamantia sidera celo, Ordine quadrifido solari currere ciclo Orridus est aquilo frigentia climate celo etc.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.title: De positione et cursu septem planetarum
msItem.rubric: De positione et cursu septem planetarum
msItem.incipit: Inter caelum et terram certis
msItem.explicit: ad easdem uices exit.
msItem.decoNote: On f.122r the bust medallions of the planets.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.title: De intervallis earum
msItem.incipit: Interualla eorum a terra multi indagare
msItem.explicit: diapason armoniam uocant.
msItem.decoNote: On f.122r parallel to the text a list of the planets with the intervalls in between. On f.122v a circular diagram of the planetary intervals.
On f.123r a rectangular diagram of the planetary latitudes.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.incipit: Tres autem quas supra solem diximus
msItem.explicit: ut subiecta figura demonstrate.
msItem.decoNote: On f.124r a circular diagram of the planetaryabsides.

msItem.note: Excerpts fromAnnalis libellus, c. 69b-c and Libri computi, Lib. IIII, 24-26.
msItem.incipit: Eclypsin solis ei quotiens luna XXX ad eandem lineam qua sol uehitur
msItem.explicit: quotidie tardius ueniret tardius recederet.
msItem.note: Astronomical notes on the place of the planets in the zodiacal band for the years 770 and 794:Anno DCCLXX indictione VIII prima die ianuari mensis stella saturni nec non et stella iouis in siderecri uersabantur. Et cuicumque codicellus iste perueniat in manus si tamen curiosit errantium recognoscere siderum cursus intellegat post quanta annorum curricula ad idem redeant sidus. Anno dominice DCCXCIIII indictione V stellarum in mense marti in geminis et stella iouis in scorpione stella martis in cancro et stella ueneris in tauro uersatur. Discite o iuuenes cum abraham caeli et siderum cursus cognoscere non cum ępicurio uoluptatum ad sertore uentri deseruire et luxuriae.

msItem.author: (Ps.) Bede
msItem.title: Opusculum Itaque stella veneris et mercurii
msItem.incipit: Itaque stella ueneris et mercurio hoc superioribus tribus planetarum stellis differunt
msItem.explicit: et idcirco longiores aetheris meta peragit.

msItem.author: (Ps.) Bede
msItem.title: De apsidibus planetarum
msItem.incipit: Circulus zodiacus qui duodecim signis constat omni ex parte aequeuicinus est terre
msItem.explicit: sed potius LXX dierum numerum reddat.

msItem.title: In quo signo versetur mars
msItem.incipit: In quo signo uersetur mars Annis ab inicio mundi
msItem.explicit: inueniri planetam. Virgo latitudinem signiferi scandes.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.title: De cursu earum per zodiacum circulum
msItem.rubric: De sursu earum per zodiacum circulum
msItem.incipit: Cur autem magnitudines suas et colores mutent
msItem.explicit: maxime inobseruabilis est cursus.

msItem.note: Excerpt fromLibri computi, V, 11.
msItem.incipit: A terra ad lunam tonum esse pronunciant
msItem.explicit: id est miliaria CVIIII et CCCLXXV

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.title: De presagiis tempestatum
msItem.incipit: Etenim prqedictis difficilioribus transpire conuenit
msItem.explicit: diras tempestates praenunciant.
msItem.note: Marginal heading inCapitalis rustica for each section: solis, lunae, stellarum etc.
List of types of numbers according toAugustine's De musica:
msItem.rubric: Genera numerorum in sensibus secundum Augustinum
msItem.quote: Progressores· In actu· Occursores· In passione· Recordabiles· In memoria Sonantes· In delectatione· Iudiciales· In discretione.

msItem.note: Excerpt fromAnnalis libellus, c. 65.
msItem.rubric: Raciocinatione item de generibus numerorum in
msItem.incipit: Cardinales sunt numeri ut unus duo tres
msItem.explicit: solus solius soli alter alterius alteri.

msItem.note: A table with six columns showing how to represent number by the fingers.
msItem.incipit: III digiti sinistra manu idem auricularis medicus in pudicus usque ad VIIII continent numerum I, II VIIII
msItem.explicit: Continet dextra manus per iunsturas semper usque ad DCCCC milia C￣ D￣C￣C￣C￣C￣.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: De computo digitorum
msItem.incipit: Cum ergo dicis I minimum in leua digitum inflectens in medium palmae artum in
msItem.explicit: sed ante aures retro respicientes.

msItem.note: Short texts on measures, predominantly excerpts from theLibri computi, Lib. VI, 1-7:

msItem.incipit:
Scripulus - sex siliquae
Dimidia sextula - duo scripuli et siliquae xii
msItem.explicit: Assis siue as - duodecim unciae
msItem.note: Text in two columns with signs for eachuncia.
Excerpt fromEucherius of Lyon's Instructionum Liber, Book 2, chapter 13-15:
msItem.incipit: Talentum est pondo LXII semis quod faciunt LXX libras arrice libra
msItem.explicit: quae ecclesiae ora celebra in sermonem nostrum uertuntur ex greco.

msItem.incipit: Omne aurum purum cuiuslibet ponderisomni argento
msItem.explicit: sicut prima lectionis huius fronte praefixum est.

msItem.rubric: De mensura caerae et metalli in operibus fusilibus
msItem.incipit: In fundendis operibus cuius ponderis metallum quodlibet ad certum
msItem.explicit: auri librae XVIIII et duo decies VIII denarii quod sunt unciae tres et denarii XVI.

msItem.rubric: Ambrosii Macrobii Theodosii de mensura et magnitudine terrae et circuli per quem solis iter est
msItem.incipit: In omni orbe uel sphera medietas centrum uocatur
msItem.explicit: ambitum stadiorum habere trecenties centena milia et insuper CLXX milia.

msItem.rubric: Item eiusdem de mensura et magnitudine solis
msItem.incipit: His dictis quibus mensura quam terrae uel ambitus uel diametros habet
msItem.explicit: Ergo ex his dicendum solem occies terra esse maiorem.

msItem.incipit: Luna item circuli sui sexcensimam optinet portionem
msItem.explicit: Ipsum uero circulum centies maiorem esse tellure.

msItem.rubric: Eiusdem argumentum quo magnitudo terrae depraehensa est
msItem.incipit: Eratostenes philosophus idemque geometra subtilissimus magnitudinem terraeni orbis nosse uolens
msItem.explicit: nullam humanae coniecturae dimensionem admittit.

msItem.note: Further excerpts fromLibri computi, Lib. IV, 31a-33a and V, 10:

msItem.rubric: Argumentum quot horas luna in unaquaque nocte luceat
msItem.incipit: Si uis scire quot horas luna in unaquaque lucet nocte
msItem.explicit: iterum descendit computandi racio.

msItem.incipit: Traditur autem secundum quosdam argumentum
msItem.explicit: pro punctis iii semisse pro ii quadrante pro uno.

msItem.incipit: Si quis nosse desiderat qua hora luna renouetur
msItem.explicit: in decimae horae noctis primo puncto finem accipit.

msItem.rubric: De solis eclypsi quando visa sit
msItem.incipit: Anno dominicae incarnationis DCCLX facta est eclypsis solis
msItem.explicit: Item anno DCCCXII fuit eclypsis solis idus maii hora diei quasi septima in XXVIIII parte tauri.

msItem.note: Excerpt fromServius' In Vergilii carmina commentarii, 10, v. 272.
msItem.incipit: Hanc stellam electram dicunt cum qua iuppiter concubuit
msItem.explicit: rapinas bella et caetera mala significat.
msItem.note: Later annotations in the margin.
A collection of computisticalargumenta predominantly taken from Libri computi, Lectiones conputi and Annalis libellus.

msItem.title: Argumentum ad lunam
msItem.rubric: Argumentum ad lune cursum turbatum anno domini infrascripto aquis palatio repertum est
msItem.incipit: Anno ab incarnatione domini DCCXVI quod raro aliquando euenit
msItem.explicit: sine ulla alia interpositione ueniunt.

msItem.rubric: Incipit computatio circuli magni paschae quigentorum XXX annorum duorum in se ipsum revolve

msItem.incipit: Vernum tempus ingreditur VIII kalendis marti
msItem.explicit: proceritas eius et altitudo XXIIIIor pedes.

msItem.incipit: Diuisiones temporum XIIII sunt id est athomus momentum
msItem.explicit: de prima diuisione temporis quam athomum diximus.

msItem.incipit: Diuisiones temporum sunt XIIII id est athomus momentum
msItem.explicit: mundus uero est uniuersitas que constat caelo terra et mari.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Letter to Wicthede
msItem.incipit: Reuerentissimo ac sansctissimo fratri uictheda
msItem.explicit: aut ante aequinoctium fuisset confirmet.

msItem.note: Blank.

msItem.title: Excerptum de astrologia
msItem.incipit: Duo sunt extremi uertices mundi
msItem.explicit: ad ipsum usque currit accipiens.

msItem.note: Verses:
msItem.incipit: Ab ioue principium magno deduxit aratus
msItem.explicit: Vatibus ignotis priscis sine honore feruntur.

msItem.note: Scholia:
msItem.incipit: Quaeritur quare ab ioue coepit et non a musis
msItem.explicit: mortalibus portat uirgo figuratur stellis XVIIII.

msItem.note: Later addition (s.XII2?) historical introduction in the art of computus.
msItem.incipit: De annis domini de quibus tanta dubitacio est intercalculatores qui existunt in arte compotipariciores de pluribus libris excerpsi
msItem.explicit: Septuaginta uero interpretes, multum ab hac supputatione annorum dissentiunt.

msItem.note: Blank.
Calendrics:
Calendar of the 12 months. Cf.Libri computi, Lib. I, 3.
TableLitterae punctatae.
Pagina regulares.
Lunar Letters A-K table.
Table with rules for the intercalation.
Table for the monthly lunar epacts. The table was accompanieed by a text, which was erased. Only an initial P visible.

msItem.rubric: Cursus lunaris de diebus singulis per XVIIII annos
msItem.note: Lunar table for the 19-year cycle with explanatory text on f. 184vIn isto predicto circulo ostenditur aetas naturalis lunae in unoquoque die .
Calendrical verses.

msItem.incipit: Ianuarius. Hic iani mensis sacer est
msItem.explicit: Nunc tibi cum domino ludere uerna licent

msItem.note: Verse on the zodiac taken fromCicero's Aratea (vv.329-331, 320-328):
msItem.incipit: Primus adest aries obscuro lumine labens
msItem.explicit: Exin squamiferi serpentes ludere pisces.

msItem.incipit: Primus romanas ordinis iane kalendas
msItem.explicit: Umbrifera mensis cumque december adest.

msItem.rubric: Item versus de numero dierum singulorum mensium
msItem.incipit: Dira patet iani romanis ianua bellis
msItem.explicit: Unde december amat te genealis hiemps.

msItem.note: Written in two columns, 44 lines as the Aratea; on185v – only two lines written the rest left blank.
On the duration of the day and the night throughout the year.
msItem.incipit: In una parte zodiaci id est in XXIIIIor horis et XXI ostentis adcrescunt diei uel nocti ostenta IIIIor In una die et XXor ostento adcrescunt ostenta IIIIor In tredecim diebus et CCLXXIII ostentis adcrescunt ostenta LII In XV partibus zodiaci adcrescit hora una Partes XC quarta pars anni solaris est
msItem.explicit: In utroque aequinoccio dies habet horas XII. Nox horas XII.
msItem.note: A table showing the length of the day for each day of the yearI KL IAN dies horarum VI et puncta IIIor .

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: EtymologiaeLib. V, 28-39
msItem.note: List of chapters on previous f. 190v.
msItem.incipit: Cronica greci dicitur quae latine temporum series apellatur
msItem.explicit: Eracleus annos XXVII huius V￣DCCCXXXIII.

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: EtymologiaeLib. III, 24-71

msItem.note: List of chapters:
msItem.incipit: I. De astronomiae nominae. II De inuentoribus astronomiae
Astronomia est astrotum lex quae cursus siderum
msItem.explicit: et insuperna contemplacione conlocaret.

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: EtymologiaeLib. XIII, 1-11

msItem.note: List of chapters:
msItem.incipit: I. De mundo. II. De athomis

msItem.rubric: In hoc vero libello quasi in brevi tabella quasdam caeli causas situsque terrarum et maris spacia adnotavimus ut in modico lector ea percurrat et compendiosa brevitate ethimologias eorum causasque cognoscat
msItem.incipit: Mundus est celum terra mare et que in eis pera dei
msItem.explicit: poete ut alitis austris.

msItem.note: Dies egyptiaci.

msItem.incipit: Mense ianuario intrante die primo secundo exiente die septimo
msItem.explicit: isti dies per omnia obseruandi sunt.

msItem.incipit: Mense ianuario die secundo et VI et XVI sanguinem noli minuare
msItem.explicit: ab illo studium declinare memento.

msItem.incipit: Item ubi abuerit ianuarii dies IIII et dies VI aut dies XXX
msItem.explicit: III ides decembri XVIII kalendas ianuarii.

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: EtymologiaeLib. IX, 5-6,22
msItem.incipit: Heredis nomen inposuit census heris
msItem.explicit: cognati, cognate, progenitores, progenetrices, Germani, Germanae.
msItem.note: On f. 201v – three column table with headingItem de predictis affinitatibus and family realtions: Auctor mei generis -- michi pater est -- ego illi filius aut filia
